chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person with suspected faltering growth?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Take a history asking about:

  • The specific concerns of the parents/carers or other healthcare professionals.
  • Feeding or eating patterns:
    • What is eaten, how much, and how often (a 3 day feeding diary may be helpful) — check food is age appropriate.
    • Amount and type of liquid consumed:
      • In breastfed infants ask about problems with breastfeeding (such as pain, difficulty with attachment, mastitis, inverted nipples, or thrush).
      • In formula fed infants check how formula is prepared.
      • Excess liquid (such as water, milk or juice) leading to satiety before meals is a common problem in toddlers.
    • Environment/family eating patterns, behaviour at mealtime (such as spitting, refusal, distress or avoidance of feeding) and parent/carer responses.
      • Consider direct observation of feeding/meal times by a person with appropriate expertise (such as a health visitor).
  • Associated symptoms
    • Associated symptoms such as fever, pain, coughing, shortness of breath, dysphagia, vomiting, or diarrhoea may indicate acute or chronic illness.
  • Pregnancy and birth history
    • Ask about complications (such as intrauterine growth restriction), birth weight, and prematurity.
  • Past medical history including:
    • Congenital abnormalities (such as cerebral palsy or Down's syndrome).
    • Developmental delay.
    • Gastrointestinal, respiratory, immunological, metabolic, endocrine or other known conditions or chronic symptoms.
    • Allergies and food intolerances.
  • Psychosocial history, including:
    • Social circumstances, for example, who is at home and access to food.
    • Family stress such as divorce, housing, or financial problems.
    • Substance and domestic abuse.
    • Health beliefs — may result in a restricted diet.
    • Maternal depression and anxiety.
  • Family history including:
    • Familial disorders such as coeliac disease, inflammatory bowel disease, and endocrine disorders.
    • Parental mental health.
    • Constitutional growth delay in parents.
    • If possible, biological parents' heights to calculate the mid-parental height centile.

Check growth plots:

  • Measure and plot current weight and replot previous growth parameters on the appropriate centile chart to confirm that faltering growth is truly present — all previous growth measurements for the child should be recorded in the parent or carer-held Personal Child Health Record.
    • UK-World Health Organisation growth charts and guidance for measuring children, plotting and interpreting growth charts are available on the RCPCH website (https://www.rcpch.ac.uk/resources/uk-world-health-organisation-growth-charts-guidance-health-professionals).
    • Specialized growth charts should be used for children born prematurely or with specific diagnoses such as Down's syndrome.

Examine the child for signs of acute or chronic conditions that might account for weight loss:

  • Assess vital signs including temperature, heart rate, capillary refill and respiratory rate.
  • Carry out a general examination looking for signs of dehydration, dysmorphic features, anaemia, jaundice, skin or mucosal changes, wasting, listlessness, or oedema.
  • Look for signs of maltreatment such as poor hygiene or unexplained injuries — for further information see the CKS topic on Child maltreatment - recognition and management.
  • Carry out a systems review, looking for signs of:
    • Cardiac, respiratory, gastrointestinal, neurological, endocrine or other chronic disorders or developmental delay.

Investigations:

  • Investigations should be guided by the clinical assessment and, if necessary, are usually carried out in secondary care with urgency depending on the clinical situation.
    • Non-invasive tests such as urinalysis may be appropriate in primary care.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the assessment of faltering growth are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines Postnatal care up to 8 weeks after birth [NICE, 2015] and Faltering Growth – recognition and management [NICE, 2017] and expert opinion in review articles [Bergman, 2005; Block, 2005; Stephens, 2008; Jaffe, 2011; Marchand, 2012; Shields, 2012; Kerzner, 2015; Homan, 2016; Larson-Nath, 2016; Gonzalez-Viana, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018].

  • Pregnancy and birth history
    • Expert opinion in review articles is that complications related to pregnancy (such as exposure to toxins or infection), prematurity and congenital disorders can be risk factors for faltering growth in childhood [Stephens, 2008; Jaffe, 2011; Homan, 2016; Larson-Nath, 2016; BMJ Best Practice, 2018].
  • Food diary
    • The NICE guideline on faltering growth [NICE, 2017] recommends use of a diary recording food intake (types and amounts) and mealtime issues (for example, settings and behaviour) to help inform management strategies and assess progress.
  • Psychosocial history
    • Expert opinion in review articles is that both medical and psychosocial problems may contribute to faltering growth. Identification of an organic pathology does not exclude additional psychosocial contributing factors — a thorough history is essential [Bergman, 2005; Block, 2005; Stephens, 2008; Homan, 2016; BMJ Best Practice, 2018].
    • Evidence on the impact of maternal depression is inconsistent:
      • A population based birth cohort study (n=12391) found no significant association between maternal postnatal depression (measured by the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS) and faltering growth in the baby [Drewett, 2004].
      • Another study (n=774) using data from a prospective birth cohort found a significant association between maternal depression and thrive index at 4 months, but only in deprived groups [Wright, 2006].
  • Child maltreatment
    • Most cases of faltering growth are not due to child maltreatment but this must always be considered as part of a thorough assessment [Bergman, 2005; Stephens, 2008].
    • A UK cohort study (n= 97) where weight faltering was identified by population screening found that rates of neglect and abuse were higher than expected in the general population, but constituted only 5% of the study population [Wright, 2000a].
    • A prospective population based study (n=2609) in inner city London found the risk of being placed on the child protection register to be four to five times higher in children with faltering weight than in controls [Skuse, 1995].
  • Investigations
    • The NICE guideline on faltering weight [NICE, 2017] recommends that further investigations should only be carried out when indicated based on the clinical assessment [NICE, 2017]  and expert opinion in a review article is that investigations should be deferred until paediatric assessment has taken place [Shields, 2012].
    • Expert opinion in the NICE guideline and review articles agree that investigations are unlikely to reveal an underlying disorder in a child with faltering growth who appears well with no other clinical concerns [NICE, 2017; Gonzalez-Viana, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018].
